metadata.description: The data set includes cumulative 3-D deformation variables recorded by 50 continuous and mobile GPS stations 5 years after the 2015 mw7.8 Nepal earthquake. Data from published articles: Zhang, J., Zhao, B., Wang, D., Yu, J., and tan, K. (2021), dynamic modeling of postseismic deformation following the 2015 MW 7.8 Gorkha earth, Nepal, J. Asian Earth SCI., 215104781, Doi: 10.1016/j.jseaes.2021.104781. The post earthquake deformation data processing process is as follows: firstly, the original observation data are processed to obtain the time series under ITRF reference frame; Then, other effects unrelated to the Nepal earthquake, such as seasonal variation, interannual variation, plate effect, etc., are corrected; Thirdly, the post earthquake time series curve is fitted by logarithmic function; Finally, the post earthquake deformation of any period is calculated by fitting the curve. Five years after the earthquake, the accumulated deformation is nearly 13.8 cm. The horizontal accuracy is not less than 0.6cm, and the vertical accuracy is not less than 2.0cm.

background: The MHT system is a detachment surface between the subducting Indian Plate and the Eurasian Plate and accommodates a high convergence rate of ~20 mm/yr. Records show that there have been a handful of strong earthquakes along the central Himalaya arc, such as the 1505 Mw > 8.2 Lo Mustang earthquake, 1833 Mw 7.7 Kathmandu earthquake, 1934 Mw 8.2 Bihar-Nepal earthquake. Postseismic transient deformation of mantle and crustal rocks is the mechanical response to stress perturbations generated by large earthquakes. The primary mechanisms of postseismic stress relaxation comprise aseismic slip in the periphery of the coseismic rupture area and viscoelastic relaxation in the lower crust and upper mantle and poroelastic rebound in the shallow crust around the fault. In recent decades, more and more geophysicists have employed three-dimensional finite element method to simulate postseismic evolution, which can solve some problems that are challenging to the traditional analytical or semi-analytical methods.
research objective: We develop three-dimensional finite element models incorporating a subducting India slab to investigate the dynamic mechanisms of postseismic deformation processes following the 2015 Mw 7.8 Gorkha earthquake based on nearly 5 years of GPS data in Nepal and southern Tibet. In this work, we present three-dimensional finite-element models (FEM) consisting of subducting Indian slab to constrain the rheological properties of the lower crust in the southern Tibetan Plateau and the frictional properties of the MHT using dense GPS observations spanning nearly 5 years both in Nepal and the southern Tibet.
challenges: However, the employed GPS data were either confined in Nepal or located hundreds of kilometer away from the rupture in the southern Tibet region. There was almost no data at approximately 150 – 250 km (intermediate-field) from the rupture area in Tibet. There are still several controversies about the distribution of the inferred afterslip and the Indian-Asian tectonic plate boundary below Tibet. In addition, most of the aforementioned postseismic modeling effects of the Gorkha earthquake adopted analytic or semi-analytic methods of dislocations theory in a homogeneous or layered elastic half-space. There may be a bias in their slip models due to the strong lateral heterogeneous rheological structure in the study area.
methods: We initially investigate the pattern of postseismic deformation from individual stress-driven afterslip and viscoelastic relaxation, and then address the contributions of combined mechanisms by meticulously evaluating the misfit between the simulated and observed surface displacements. We process the raw GPS data using the GAMIT/GLOBK version 10.7 processing software.
dataset: We also collected the observations of three continuous GPS (cGPS) stations and previously unpublished data at 7 campaign GPS stations (J040, JB54, J339, J030, J337, J038, J338) in the southern Tibet from the Crustal Movement Observation Network of China (CMONOC).
findings: The preferred combined model reproduces the postseismic deformation associated with the Gorkha earthquake and indicates that near- to intermediate-field postseismic displacements are mainly caused by aseismic slip on the downdip of the coseismic rupture, while the far-field deformation is dominated by viscoelastic relaxation in the lower crust and upper mantle of the southern Tibet. The steady-state viscosity of the lower crust in the southern Tibet is estimated to be 3 × 10^18 Pa s, corresponding transient-state viscosity is 3 × 10^17 Pa s. The best-fit combined model suggests that approximately 90% afterslip was released in the first 4 years and corresponding frictional parameter a σ = 0.15 MPa. Additionally, we find the afterslip fringing the downdip of the coseismic rupture plays an important role in the trade-off between near- and intermediate-field displacements. Afterslip deficit in the shallow part of the Main Himalayan Thrust indicates the potential seismic hazard on the south and west of Kathmandu in future.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how GPS data is processed to remove unrelated influences such as seasonal variations and tectonic plate effects when studying earthquake-induced deformation?
Example.Answer: To study earthquake-induced deformation, raw GPS data is processed by first obtaining a time series in the ITRF reference frame. Then, corrections are applied to remove unrelated influences such as seasonal variations, annual changes, and tectonic plate effects. A logarithmic function is used to fit the postseismic time series curve, allowing for the calculation of deformation over any time period.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using GPS data to model postseismic deformation in regions with sparse data coverage?
Example.Answer: A challenge in using GPS data to model postseismic deformation is the lack of data in certain regions, such as the approximately 150-250 km intermediate-field from the rupture area in Tibet. This lack of data can lead to controversies regarding the distribution of inferred afterslip and the tectonic plate boundary, potentially causing biases in slip models due to strong lateral heterogeneous rheological structures.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of how combined mechanisms like afterslip and viscoelastic relaxation are evaluated to simulate postseismic deformation?
Example.Answer: Combined mechanisms such as afterslip and viscoelastic relaxation are evaluated by investigating the pattern of postseismic deformation from individual stress-driven afterslip and viscoelastic relaxation. The contributions of these combined mechanisms are assessed by meticulously evaluating the misfit between simulated and observed surface displacements, using three-dimensional finite element models to constrain rheological properties and frictional parameters.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'postseismic deformation' in the context of geophysical studies?
Definition.Answer: Postseismic deformation refers to the mechanical response of mantle and crustal rocks to stress perturbations generated by large earthquakes. It mainly involves aseismic slip in the periphery of the coseismic rupture area, viscoelastic relaxation in the lower crust and upper mantle, and poroelastic rebound in the shallow crust around the fault.

Definition.Question: How is 'afterslip' characterized in studies of postseismic deformation?
Definition.Answer: Afterslip is characterized as aseismic slip occurring on the downdip of the coseismic rupture, playing a crucial role in postseismic deformation. It is significant in the trade-off between near- and intermediate-field displacements and indicates potential seismic hazards if it is deficient in certain areas, such as the Main Himalayan Thrust.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of data collection in the intermediate-field region of the southern Tibet differ from those in Nepal with respect to the Gorkha earthquake postseismic studies?
Comparison.Answer: The intermediate-field region in southern Tibet faces challenges due to the lack of data approximately 150–250 km from the rupture area, creating gaps in spatial data collection. In contrast, Nepal has more concentrated GPS data closer to the rupture area, allowing for more detailed local analysis but potentially missing insights from the intermediate-field dynamics that are captured in Tibet.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences between the rheological modeling approaches used in postseismic deformation studies compared to traditional analytic or semi-analytic methods?
Comparison.Answer: Both rheological modeling approaches and traditional analytic methods aim to simulate postseismic deformation, but rheological models, particularly those using three-dimensional finite element methods, can incorporate complex geological structures like subducting slabs and heterogeneous rheological properties, offering more detailed simulations. Traditional analytic methods might simplify these structures, potentially leading to biases due to assumptions of homogeneous or layered elastic half-spaces.

Interpretation.Question: How can the absence of GPS data at approximately 150 – 250 km from the rupture area impact the interpretation of postseismic deformation patterns?
Interpretation.Answer: The absence of GPS data at approximately 150 – 250 km from the rupture area may lead to incomplete understanding of the intermediate-field postseismic deformation patterns, potentially affecting the accuracy of inferred afterslip distribution and rheological properties. This gap may cause biases in the slip models due to the heterogeneous rheological structure of the study area.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges in interpreting the contributions of individual and combined mechanisms to the postseismic deformation from the observed GPS data?
Interpretation.Answer: Interpreting the contributions of individual and combined mechanisms to postseismic deformation requires meticulous evaluation of the misfit between simulated and observed surface displacements. Challenges include differentiating between the effects of aseismic slip and viscoelastic relaxation, as well as addressing the influence of lateral heterogeneity in the rheological structure, which may introduce biases.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to the challenges in collecting GPS data for postseismic deformation analysis in regions like Nepal and southern Tibet?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in collecting GPS data for postseismic deformation analysis in Nepal and southern Tibet include the limited availability of data from the intermediate-field region approximately 150 – 250 km from the rupture area, as well as the strong lateral heterogeneous rheological structure in the study area, which may cause biases in slip models.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need to correct for seasonal and interannual variations when processing GPS data in postseismic deformation studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Correcting for seasonal and interannual variations is necessary to isolate the deformation caused by the earthquake from other influences, such as plate effects and environmental factors, ensuring that the observed displacements accurately reflect the postseismic deformation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the bias in slip models when using analytic or semi-analytic methods for postseismic modeling in the Gorkha earthquake region?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The bias in slip models arises from the use of analytic or semi-analytic methods in a homogeneous or layered elastic half-space, which do not account for the strong lateral heterogeneous rheological structure of the region, leading to potential inaccuracies in the modeling of postseismic deformation.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of incorporating both continuous and campaign GPS data from different regions on the accuracy and reliability of postseismic deformation models?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incorporating both continuous and campaign GPS data from different regions can enhance the spatial coverage and resolution of postseismic deformation models. However, it may introduce challenges related to data consistency and integration, particularly if the data are from regions with varying distances from the rupture area, such as Nepal and southern Tibet. This can affect the accuracy of inferred deformation patterns and rheological properties.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of using three-dimensional finite element models for simulating postseismic deformation compared to traditional analytic or semi-analytic methods?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using three-dimensional finite element models allows for more accurate simulations of postseismic deformation by accommodating complex geological structures and heterogeneous rheological properties. This can improve the understanding of mechanisms like aseismic slip and viscoelastic relaxation, leading to more reliable predictions of deformation patterns. However, it also requires comprehensive and high-quality data inputs, which could be challenging to obtain uniformly across the affected regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of developing three-dimensional finite element models incorporating a subducting slab for investigating postseismic deformation processes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to investigate the dynamic mechanisms of postseismic deformation processes following the 2015 Mw 7.8 Gorkha earthquake, with a focus on constraining the rheological properties of the lower crust in the southern Tibetan Plateau and the frictional properties of the Main Himalayan Thrust (MHT) using dense GPS observations spanning nearly 5 years.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to address the contributions of combined mechanisms when evaluating postseismic deformation using GPS data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Addressing the contributions of combined mechanisms is important because it allows for meticulous evaluation of the misfit between simulated and observed surface displacements, thereby improving the accuracy of the postseismic deformation model and understanding how different processes like afterslip and viscoelastic relaxation contribute to observed deformations.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended benefits of processing raw GPS data using specific software such as GAMIT/GLOBK version 10.7 in the context of postseismic deformation studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended benefits of using specific software like GAMIT/GLOBK version 10.7 for processing raw GPS data include obtaining precise and reliable time series data in the ITRF reference frame, which is crucial for accurately correcting for external influences and fitting postseismic deformation curves, thereby enhancing the understanding of cumulative postseismic deformations over time.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are necessary to correct for influences unrelated to the Nepal earthquake, such as seasonal variations or plate effects, during the GPS data processing?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedures involve processing the raw GPS data to obtain time series in the ITRF reference frame, followed by correcting for other influences unrelated to the Nepal earthquake, like seasonal variations, interannual changes, and plate effects.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can three-dimensional finite element models be employed to simulate postseismic deformation and what specific data processing steps are required to evaluate the fit between simulated and observed displacements?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Three-dimensional finite element models are used by incorporating a subducting India slab to simulate postseismic deformation. The data processing steps include initially evaluating the pattern of postseismic deformation from individual stress-driven afterslip and viscoelastic relaxation, and meticulously assessing the misfit between the simulated and observed surface displacements using GAMIT/GLOBK version 10.7 processing software.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are used to collect GPS observations in challenging terrains like southern Tibet and how is unpublished data incorporated into the analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Methods include using continuous GPS (cGPS) stations and campaign GPS stations for data collection in challenging terrains like southern Tibet. Unpublished data from 7 campaign GPS stations in the region are incorporated into the analysis alongside observations from the Crustal Movement Observation Network of China (CMONOC).

Enablement.Question: What data processing techniques enable the accurate correction of seasonal and interannual variations when analyzing GPS data for postseismic deformation studies?
Enablement.Answer: The data processing involves initially handling raw GPS data to obtain time series in the ITRF reference frame, followed by correcting for influences unrelated to the earthquake, such as seasonal and interannual variations, using sophisticated data processing software like GAMIT/GLOBK.

Expectation.Question: Why might data collection methods for postseismic deformation following large earthquakes, such as the 2015 Mw 7.8 Gorkha earthquake, face challenges in intermediate-field regions?
Expectation.Answer: The employed GPS data were either confined in Nepal or located hundreds of kilometers away from the rupture in the southern Tibet region. There was almost no data at approximately 150 – 250 km from the rupture area in Tibet, leading to challenges in data collection for these intermediate-field regions.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated challenges in using three-dimensional finite element models to simulate postseismic deformation processes in areas with a strong lateral heterogeneous rheological structure?
Expectation.Answer: Most of the postseismic modeling effects of the Gorkha earthquake adopted analytic or semi-analytic methods of dislocations theory in a homogeneous or layered elastic half-space. There may be a bias in their slip models due to the strong lateral heterogeneous rheological structure in the study area, posing challenges in achieving accurate simulation results.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the challenges faced in combining different data sources for accurate postseismic deformation modeling in the context of limited intermediate-field data availability?
Judgmental.Answer: Combining different data sources in postseismic deformation modeling presents challenges due to the limited availability of intermediate-field data, which creates gaps in coverage and may lead to biases in the slip models. The strong lateral heterogeneous rheological structure in the study area further complicates the integration of data, suggesting a need for more comprehensive data collection strategies to improve model accuracy.

Judgmental.Question: How do you perceive the role of advanced three-dimensional finite element models in enhancing the understanding of postseismic deformation mechanisms compared to traditional methods?
Judgmental.Answer: Advanced three-dimensional finite element models significantly enhance the understanding of postseismic deformation mechanisms by addressing limitations of traditional analytical or semi-analytical methods. They allow for a more detailed representation of the subducting Indian slab and the rheological properties of the lower crust, providing insights into the complex interactions that drive postseismic processes.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how could the integration of additional GPS station data improve the interpretation of afterslip and viscoelastic relaxation in postseismic studies?
Judgmental.Answer: The integration of additional GPS station data could substantially improve the interpretation of afterslip and viscoelastic relaxation by filling data gaps, particularly in the intermediate-field regions. This would provide a more complete dataset for accurately modeling the spatial distribution of postseismic deformation, enhancing the reliability of the findings and reducing potential biases related to data scarcity.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the processes involved in correcting GPS data for influences unrelated to the Nepal earthquake, such as seasonal variations or plate effects.
Assertion.Answer: The GPS data is processed by first obtaining time series in the ITRF reference frame and then correcting for unrelated influences like seasonal and interannual variations, and plate effects, to isolate the postseismic deformation related to the Nepal earthquake.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate how GPS data processing techniques have evolved in recent years to improve the accuracy of postseismic deformation measurements in tectonically active regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The GPS data processing for postseismic deformation measurements involves using software like GAMIT/GLOBK to handle raw data. The process includes correcting for unrelated influences such as seasonal changes and plate effects to achieve accuracy. Recent techniques leverage three-dimensional finite-element models to simulate postseismic deformation and address the challenges posed by strong lateral heterogeneous rheological structures.
